technology: Regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting
technology_description: Air/fuel furnace with 8% electric boosting. regenerators for air preheating, positioned at the end of the melting tank and operating with a typical energy efficiency of 70%.  Assumed batch mixing is 1% of total reference plant (regenerator with electric boosting is 80%. 19% is post-melting process)
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Approximate figure of EUR 15 million for 100 kt/yr capacity furnace mentioned by glass industry
input_1_source: Papadogeorgos & Schure (2019), Decarbonisation options for the Dutch container and tableware glass industry, PBL and TNO Energy Transition.
input_1_comment: Using data model technology 0 with 8% electric boosting, 76% cullet, no oxygen enrichment/substitution
input_2_source: Papadogeorgos & Schure, 2019
input_2_comment: Included: electricity use for batch mixing of 48 GJ/t melt
input_3_source: Papadogeorgos & Schure, 2019
input_4_source: Papadogeorgos & Schure, 2019
input_4_comment: 62.3% silica, 18.4% soda ash (sodium carbonate), 7.8% limestone (calcium carbonate), 10.9% dolomite and 0.6% sodium sulphate assumed
output_2_source: Papadogeorgos & Schure, 2019
output_2_comment: T=454 Celcius
co2_emissions_comment: emission factor natural gas 56.6 kg/GJ accounts for 85% of emissions, process emissions another 15% (10-15%)

technology: Regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting and batch/cullet preheater
technology_description: Air/fuel furnace with 8% electric boosting and regenerators. both raw materials and cullet are preheated using the flue gas heat contents.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/230949/D13_951813__Ricardo_AEA_Industrial_Decarbonisation_Literature_Review_201___.pdf
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: CAPEX from regenerative end-port furnace plus 1.5 million for preheater (EUR 1.5 million for 350 t/day capacity~100kt/yr) Assumed double that cost to account for EPC
technical_lifetime_comment: batch preheater lifetime 20 yrs. furnace lifetime extended with the use of electric boosting

technology_description: Removal of particulates/contaminants/water from the flue gases and CO2 compression into a sealed container. Storage not included. Allows for pre/post/oxyfuel combustion capturing depending on the furnace type.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: https://ec.europa.eu/clima/sites/clima/files/strategies/2050/docs/industrial_innovation_part_1_en.pdf
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: EUR 50/t packed glass=EUR45000/kt melt. Normalised to the 0.262 kt CO2 emitted/kt melt by base furnace plus 0.028 for post-melting process: 45000/.268/1.e6=0.17 MEUR/kt CO2 captured. 75% avoided, assumed 30% energy penalty of NG furnace consumption, of which 60% natural gas and rest electricity. Inputs and outputs renormalized to kt CO2 captured/compressed.
input_2_comment: Calculated based on 30% energy penalty of natural gas furnace consumption.
input_3_source: https://ec.europa.eu/clima/sites/clima/files/strategies/2050/docs/industrial_innovation_part_1_en.pdf
input_3_comment: 60% of energy is thermal, 40% is electricity. Does include storage pumping so may be too high
co2_emissions_comment: from natural gas consumption CCS system and 0.02 kt from difference in/captured
trl_source: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/415958/Glass_Appendices.pdf

technology_description: Thermal cracking furnaces that cracks EDC in VCM. Natural gas is burned to supply the heat of reaction and to bring the reactants to the required reaction temperature of 500ᵒC. The conversion efficiency of EDC to VCM is 55%.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Assumption 10 MW furnace cost is approx 15 MEUR, scaled up to 20 MW furnace with scaling factor 0.67, per MW
input_1_source: Semeijn V.P. and Schure K.M. (2019), Decarbonisation options for the Dutch PVC industry, PBL and TNO Energy Transition.

input_4_source: Energy Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
output_1_source: Mass Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
output_1_comment: The EDC cracking gas contains by weight% 32% VCM, 52% EDC, 16% HCl.
co2_emissions_comment: Calculated using 56.6 kg/GJ natural gas.

technology_description: Distillation columns that separate HCl and EDC from VCM. Both colums are treated in a single block here.

output_2_comment: EDC is recycled back to the Distillation EDC purification unit
output_3_source: Mass Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
output_3_comment: HCl is recycled back to the EDC fluid-bed reactor unit

technology_description: Suspension polymerisation reactor, stripping column, fluidised bed drying, flash drying. Reactor that polymerises VCM in PVC in the presence of water to a sludge with 44wt% water and subsequent drying steps. The reactor conversion efficiency of VCM to PVC is 85%.
input_1_source: Personal communication Shin-Etsu (25-02-2019)
input_2_source: Personal communication Shin-Etsu (25-02-2019)
input_2_comment: The overall conversion of VCM to PVC goes with little losses. Only 0.001-0.002% VCM is lost in the process.
input_3_source: Energy Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
input_4_source: Energy Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
input_4_comment: LP steam is consumed by the steam stripping to recover unconverted VCM
input_5_source: Energy Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)
input_5_comment: MP steam is consumed by the drying equipment
output_1_source: Mass Flow Analysis in Semeijn and Schure (2019)

technology: Gas-liquid contact column fed with bio-ethylene
technology_description: ethylene input is replaced by bio-ethylene produced from bio-ethanol
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_refurbis: Assumed that the bio-ethylene is readily available from the market. Furthermore, as bio-ethylene and ethylene are exactly the same chemicals, no modifications to the existing equipment is needed. Therefore, there is no CAPEX involved. However, it is uncertain when this would be a viable option as the market price for bio-ethylene is significantly higher than fossil-based ethylene. We assume that by 2025 bio-ethylene is market competitive.
technical_lifetime_comment: There is no lifetime involved with this option.

technology_description: Ammonia production by Steam Methane Reforming combined with Haber-Bosch NH3 synthesis.
input_1_source: Lako, P., Energy conservation potential of the nitrogen fertiliser industry, ECN, 2009.
input_1_comment: The input of natural gas is based on the net energy efficiency in Lako (2009). The energy efficiency is the sum of the input of natural gas, the net input of steam and the net input of electricity. Assumed is that these values are roughly representative for all 5 ammonia plants in NL, though small differences exist.
input_2_source: Industrial Efficiency Technology Database (http://ietd.iipnetwork.org/content/ammonia)
output_2_source: Industrial Efficiency Technology Database (http://ietd.iipnetwork.org/content/ammonia)
output_3_comment: high purity CO2
co2_emissions_source: Kennisgeving standaard CO2-emissiefactor aardgas voor emissiehandel 2019, Ministerie van Economische Zaken en Klimaat
co2_emissions_comment: The emission factor of natural gas is 56.6 kg CO2/GJ. Of this CO2 69% is high purity CO2, the rest combustion concentration CO2

technology_description: Ammonia production by Steam Methane Reforming combined with Haber-Bosch NH3 synthesis. Biogas as feedstock and fuel.
input_1_source: Lako, P., Energy conservation potential of the nitrogen fertiliser industry, ECN, 2009.
input_1_comment: The input of natural gas is based on the net energy efficiency in Lako (2009). The energy efficiency is the sum of the input of natural gas, the net input of steam and the net input of electricity. Assumed is that these values are roughly representative for all 5 ammonia plants in NL, though small differences exist. Biogas replaces natural gas.
input_2_source: Industrial Efficiency Technology Database (http://ietd.iipnetwork.org/content/ammonia)
output_2_source: Industrial Efficiency Technology Database (http://ietd.iipnetwork.org/content/ammonia)
output_3_comment: high purity CO2
co2_emissions_comment: Only biogenic emissions (1.93 kt/kt ammonia). Of this CO2 69% is high purity CO2, the rest combustion concentration CO2

technology_description: Nitric acid is produced by high-temperature catalytic oxidation of ammonia.
input_1_source: Yara HESQ/ TK Jenssen, „Calculation of Carbon Footprint of Fertilizer Production,” 2011.
input_2_source: Saygin, D., Assessing industrial energy use and CO2 emissions, Opportunities for energy efficiency, biomass and CCS. Utrecht: PhD thesis Utrecht University, 2012.
output_2_comment: Because of the wide range in energy export in the literature, no net energy export has been assumed.
n2o_emissions_comment: Yara Sluiskil emitted 780 ton of N2O in 2016. Assuming a production capacity for nitric acid of 1500 kt/year and 8000 full-load hours, the emission is 0.6 kg N2O/ton NA.

technology_description: Synthesis of urea is achieved by the reaction of ammonia and carbon dioxide at high pressure forming ammonium carbamate, which is then dehydrated by applying heat, forming urea and water.
input_1_source: A. Kool, M. Marinussen en H. Blonk, „LCI data for the calculation tool Feedprint for greenhouse gas emissions of feed production and utilization,” Blonk Consultants, Gouda, 2012.
input_2_source: A. Bazzanella en F. Ausfelder, „Low carbon energy and feedstock for the European chemical industry,” DECHEMA Gesellschaft für Chemische Technik und Biotechnologie e.V., Frankfurt am Main, 2017.
input_3_source: IEA, „Energy technology transtions for industry, Strategies for the next industrial revolution,” IEA/OECD, Paris, 2009.
input_3_comment: Best Practise Technology value.
input_4_source: IEA, „Energy technology transtions for industry, Strategies for the next industrial revolution,” IEA/OECD, Paris, 2009.
input_4_comment: Best Practise Technology value.

technology_description: Ammonia production by electrolysis of water combined with Haber-Bosch NH3 synthesis.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Stork M, De Beer J, Lintmeijer N and Den Ouden B. (2018). Chemistry for Climate: Acting on the need for speed. Roadmap for the Dutch Chemical Industry towards 2050. Ecofys, Berenschot..Benner J, Van Lieshout M and Croezen H. (2011). Identifying breakthrough technologies for the production of basic chemicals. A long term view on the sustainable production of ammonia, olefins and aromatics in the European region. Delft: CE Delft..ISPT (2017). Power to ammonia - Feasibility study for the value chains and business cases to produce CO2-free ammonia suitable for various market applications. ISPT, Amersfoort.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The investment costs for hydrogen electrolysis are EUR 525/kW. The  specific power consumption is 53 kWh per kg H2 produced. The calculation asssumes  8.000 operating hours per year. Per ton of ammonia, 178 kg of hydrogen is needed. The lower heating value of hydrogen is 120 MJ/kg H2. Investments for the Air Separation Unit are estimated to be EUR 27/t NH3. The electricity needed for compressors and the air separation unit is 1.73 MWh/ton ammonia.
technical_lifetime_source: ISPT, „Power to ammonia - Feasibility study for the value chains and business cases to produce CO2-free ammonia suitable for various market applications,” ISPT, Amersfoort, 2017.
technical_lifetime_comment: The lifetime of PEM-electrolysers is around 10 years.
input_1_source: Benner J, Van Lieshout M and Croezen H. (2011). Identifying breakthrough technologies for the production of basic chemicals. A long term view on the sustainable production of ammonia, olefins and aromatics in the European region. Delft: CE Delft..ISPT (2017). Power to ammonia - Feasibility study for the value chains and business cases to produce CO2-free ammonia suitable for various market applications. ISPT, Amersfoort.
input_1_comment: The  specific power consumption is 53 kWh per kg H2 produced.Per ton of ammonia, 178 kg of hydrogen is needed. The lower heating value of hydrogen is 120 MJ/kg H2. The electricity needed for compressors and the air separation unit is 1.73 MWh/ton ammonia.

technology_description: The dryers use the flue gas from the combustion of the tail-gas in a combustion chamber.

input_2_source: Estimation

technology_description: The boilers are waste gas boilers which produce steam from the combustion of the tail gas.

technology_description: The steam turbine is used to produce electricity from the steam generated in the boilers.

technology: TDM reactor (methane burner, isolated quench chamber, cyclone and filter)

technology: Methyl Ethyl Ketone (MEK)- SBA dehydrogenation process - electric furnace
technology_description: Methyl Ethyl Ketone (MEK)- SBA dehydrogenation process - electric furnace
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Minimum: Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties. Maximum: DNVGL/VNPI (2018), CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: According to Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties, an electric cracking furnace would have investment costs of 0.6-4.5 MEUR/MWth. This is for a typical capacity of 5-10 MW and 3600-8760 h/y. For comparison, Semeijn and Schure (2020) use a capex of 2.8-4 MEUR/MW for a 20 MW furnace, which is within the range. VNPI costs include substation, cabling, equipment and project handling for a furnace with 10MWth capacity. Navigant report  does not detail what is included in the figure
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_refurbis: no reliable information available
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Minimum: Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties. Maximum: DNVGL/VNPI (2018), CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen
Based on the range 0.5-2% CAPEX. Fixed OPEX only, it does not include electricity costs
technical_lifetime_comment: no reliable information available
input_1_comment: assumed same as base technology
input_2_comment: assumed same as base technology
input_3_comment: assumption: all fuel replaced by electricity. Estimation: same efficiency
output_2_comment: assumed same as base technology
trl_source: https://www.iea.org/articles/etp-clean-energy-technology-guide
trl_comment: TRL for a generic electric furnace for heating purposes.

technology: Methyl Ethyl Ketone (MEK)- SBA dehydrogenation process - hydrogen fired furnace
technology_description: hydrogen fired furnace for MEK - SBA dehydrogenation process
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: VNPI (2018) CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Cost includes costs for the infrastructure for hydrogen transport, hydrogen compressor, replacement of natural gas burners and installation of NOx emissions based on a 17 MW furnace. 17 MW is calculated based on a capacity of 90 kt MEK/y and steam demand of 6 GJ/t required by the process.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: VNPI (2018), CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen.
technical_lifetime_source: Assumption
technical_lifetime_comment: Assumed numbers for traditional cracking furnaces.

technology_description: Chemical process in producing propylene oxide & styrene monomer
input_1_source: Falcke (2018) Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for  the Production of Large Volume Organic Chemicals - Industrial Emissions Directive  2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution  Prevention and Control)
input_2_comment: Approximated based on propylene: propylene oxide stoichiometric ratio of 1:1
input_3_source: Tebodin. (2017). Veiligheidsrapport – Gesterde delen Lyondell Chemie Nederland B.V. locatie Maasvlakte Deel 0 en 1.
input_3_comment: Approximated based on maximum annual required quantity indicated in (Tebodin, 2017)
input_4_source: Hydrocarbon Processing (2010) Petrochemical Processes 2010. Falcke (2018) Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for  the Production of Large Volume Organic Chemicals - Industrial Emissions Directive  2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution  Prevention and Control)
input_4_comment: Refers to net steam input from external utility company(ies). This assumes a gross steam input of 11.16 GJ/tonne SM (value range between 11.16 and 14.04 GJ/tonne of SM (Hydrocarbon Processing, 2010)), as well as utilisation of recovered heat from benzene alkylation process and PO/SM process, with an amount of 4.19 (Hydrocarbon Processing, 2010) and 1.08 (Falcke, et al., 2018) GJ/ tonne of SM , respectively.  Temperature/pressure level unknown.
input_5_source: Falcke (2018) Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for  the Production of Large Volume Organic Chemicals - Industrial Emissions Directive  2010/75/EU (Integrated Pollution  Prevention and Control)
output_2_comment: Approximated based on production capacities of propylene oxide and styrene monomer
output_3_comment: annual waste fuel output includes propane (8kt/year), glycolic fuel (12kt/year), heavy liquid fuel (including heavy aromatics solvents from benzene alkylation. 30.1kt/year), fuel gas (10.5 kt/year) and other combustible stream (RFO-637. 40.3kt/year). 0.12 kt per kt of styrene monomer. Converted to energy based on Yong et al. (2021). (excluding RFO-637).

input_2_source: Ghanta, M., Fahey, D., Busch, D., & Subramaniam, B. (2013). Comparative Economic and Environmental Assessments of H2O2 -based and Tertiary Butyl Hydroperoxide-based Propylene Oxide Technologies.

technology_description: By increasing the wettability of the cathode surface of a electrolysis reduction cell, the electrical contact between the liquid aluminium and the carbon cathode improves, and the anode to cathode distance can be reduced. With a fully-drained sloped cathode design, electricity savings can be achieved, and PFC emissions can be reduced.

investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Source states 35-50 MEUR for 10 MW furnace. Based on annual NG use of the present furnaces and capacity utilisation ratios, we estimate a power capacity of 4 MWth in total (for an annual production of 16 kt of monomers). Therefore, we assume that a cost of 35-50 MEUR for 10 MWth corresponds to 35-50 MEUR for 40 kt of monomers. We apply linear scaling as first rough estimate.

input_1_source: Assumption
input_1_comment: Assuming an annual destruction of 100 Tonne of F-gasses (which is an amount used in several clean development mechanism projects to destroy F-gasses). Efficiency of 99.9%, so 100 tonnes input corresponds to 1 tonnne output
input_2_source: Chen, S., Živný, O., Mašláni, A., & Chau, S. (2019). Abatement of fluorinated compounds in thermal plasma flow. Journal of Fluorine Chemistry, 217, 41-49. doi:10.1016/j.jfluchem.2018.10.004
input_2_comment: Estimation based on literature review (Chen et al.,2019). Assuming 100% of utilization and taking an input capacity of 150 the calculation would be: 150KW*8760h/(27.777 (TJ/KWh))=4,73 TJ.  Assuming an annual rate of 100 Tonne of F-gases to be destroyed, it would be the input per 100 kt

technology: Steam cracker with hydrogen as fuel
technology_description: Cracker furnaces fueled by hydrogen combustion

investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Cost includes costs for the infrastructure for hydrogen transport, hydrogen compressor, replacement of natural gas burners and installation of NOx emissions based on a total of 1 GW total furnace power. 360 MW is assumed to be less complex and the remainder is more complex, thus the upper cost limit may account for the more complex part.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_refurbis: MEUR2019
TNO (2019). H- Vision - Blue hydrogen as accelerator and pioneer for energy transition in the Industry. Rotterdam: Deltalinqs/TNO

Assumption: total furnace power is 1 GW (2300 kt HVC, 15 GJ/t). 150 kEUR/MW to adapt burners, for first 360 MW (H-vision). Assumption: Double price for further 650-700 MW (H-vision). Total ~250 MEUR for 2300 kt. Excluding pipelines to hydrogen plant

technology_description: Electric cracker
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Minimum: Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties. Maximum: DNVGL/VNPI (2018), CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: According to Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties, an electric cracking furnace would have investment costs of 0.6-4.5 MEUR/MWth. This is for a typical capacity of 5-10 MW and 3600-8760 h/y. For comparison, Semeijn and Schure (2020) use a capex of 2.8-4 MEUR/MW for a 20 MW furnace, which is within the range. VNPI costs include substation, cabling, equipment and project handling for a furnace with 10MWth capacity. Navigant report  does not detail what is included in the figure
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Minimum: Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties. Maximum: DNVGL/VNPI (2018), CO2 reductie roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen
Based on the range 0.5-2% CAPEX. Fixed OPEX only, it does not include electriciy costs
technical_lifetime_comment: Navigant (2019), Verkenning uitbreiding SDE met industriele opties

Based on 5.5 MW,input reference digester. Fixed operational costs are 111 €/kW input/ yr

input_1_comment: Estimate based on 62% efficiency
output_1_source: Boots, Wolbers, & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Vergisting van biomassa.
co2_emissions_source: Boots, Wolbers, & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Vergisting van biomassa.
co2_emissions_comment: In reality, CO2 is emitted when biomass like spent grains are burned. However, emissions from the burning of biomass are allocated to the point where the biomass is produced and harvested. Next to this, the spent grains are a rest product that are produced either way in the production process of maltings or breweries. Hence, the emissions from the use of biomass by the breweries or maltings are considered to be zero.
trl_source: Boots, Wolbers, & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Vergisting van biomassa.

technology_description: Excess residual heat from other industries could be captured and transport to provide heat to another industry
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Reference 10 MWth project. Investment cost are including a 10 km pipeline from the heat producer to the heat offtaker. Investment costs are 1411 €/kWth output.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.

Reference 10 MWth project. Fixed operation costs are 29 €/kWth output/yr. Variable operation costs are 0.001€/kWhth, Note that variable operational costs are not included in the reported value since this is highly dependend on the electricity price which is highly volatile and country specific.
technical_lifetime_source: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.
technical_lifetime_comment: The reported economical lifetime is 15 year, but the technical lifetime is generally longer (up to 30 years).
input_1_source: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.
input_1_comment: Electricity is used in transportation pumps and heat exchangers. When green electricity is used, the emissions are assumed to be 0.
output_1_source: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.
co2_emissions_source: Muller & Lensink. 2020. Conceptadvies SDE++ 2021 Benutting restwarmte uit industrie of datacenters.
co2_emissions_comment: In reality, CO2 is emitted in the industrial processes that precede the waste heat production. However, these emissions could be counted zero when this left-over heat would otherwise be wasted to the environment. Furthermore, some electricity is needed for the transportation pumps and heat exchanger, but these are assumed to be 0 when green electricity is used

technology_description: Biofuel dryer to replace the natural gas one to produce the heat needed. Considering buying green gas / SNG as a utility (input).
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Likely little additional costs since green gas can probably be used in the current drying facilities

The main operational cost would be sourcing the SNG feedstock. The operation and Maitenence are considered to be the costs of O&M for storage and usage of the SNG. Energy costs are not considered. The literature describes the operational costs for this case as being 2% of the CAPEX for production. The CAPEX for production, is considered to be (in the same document) 0,08 EUR/m3 in 2050. Considering the consumption of NSG needed by the dryer, the results are stated above.

CWT approach  is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. CWT stands Solomon “CO2 weighted tonne” (CWT) approach. co2_emissions_source: Methodology for the free allocation of emission allowances in the EU ETS post 2012. Ecofys, Fraunhofer ISI and Öko-Institut (November, 2009)
co2_emissions_comment: CO2 emissions were calculated based on the CWT approach, which is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. CWT stands Solomon “CO2 weighted tonne” (CWT) approach. Each process unit presents a standard CWT factor which refers to the net energy consumption and can be translated to CO2 emissions via the formula CO2 emissions = 1,083*0,0295*Unit throughtput*CWT factor. For the flexicoking unit the CWT factor is 16,6. More detailed information can be found at source mentioned in this dataset.

technology: Atmospheric distillation with hydrogen as fuel
technology_description: Crude oil atmospheric distillation to several fractions
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_refurbis: kEUR2017
CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen (VNPI, 2018)

Investment costs based on 10 MWth furnace and include extra pipeline, hydrogen compressor and burners adjustment. The average cost only for the adjustment of the furnace's burners is around 100 kEUR 2017/MWth. The costs for NOX emissions reduction abatement is not considered here, but this device is needed. The extra pipeline can differ significantly depending on the site.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen (VNPI, 2018)
technical_lifetime_comment: assumption based on average lifetime of conventional gas-fired furnaces
input_1_source: calculated
input_1_comment: The product fractions resulted from athmospheric distillation are highly dependent on the crude oil used. The values are based on a Brent blend crude oil (density: 825 kg/m³). The crude oil used as a reference yields 0,27 t naphtha/ t crude oil (light + heavy naphtha)
input_2_source: Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the Refining of Mineral Oil and Gas (JRC, 2015)
input_2_comment: Fuel usage is around 0,538 GJ/t crude oil intake for Brent blend crude oil atmospheric distillation. The hydrogen furnace thermal efficiency was assumed to be the same as the conventional furnace (around 90%)
input_3_source: Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the Refining of Mineral Oil and Gas (JRC, 2015)
input_3_comment: Electricity consumption is around 5,1 kWh/t crude oil intake
input_4_source: Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the Refining of Mineral Oil and Gas (JRC, 2015)
input_4_comment: Assuming that the steam consumption in the process unit will remain unchanged with hydrogen furnaces.

output_1_comment: considered as main output
output_2_source: calculated
output_2_comment: Based on Brent blend oil assay, which yields 0,15 t kerosene/ t crude oil
output_3_source: calculated
output_3_comment: Based on Brent blend oil assay, which yields 0,17 t diesel/ t crude oil
output_4_source: calculated
output_4_comment: Based on Brent blend oil assay, which yields 0,27 t vacuum gasoil/ t crude oil
output_5_source: calculated
output_5_comment: Based on Brent blend oil assay, which yields 0,11 t vacuum residue/ t crude oil
output_6_comment: Based on Brent blend oil assay, which yields 0,02 t refinery gas/ t crude oil. A LHV of 45,2 MJ/kg was considered
co2_emissions_comment: direct emissions are zero. hydrogen source is important for full evaluation
trl_source: Rutten, L., Technology factsheet: H2 industrial boiler, TNO, 2020
trl_comment: Hydrogen burners are available and sometimes used at sites with available by-product hydrogen. They are used commercially in some industrial niches, although there is currently no wider market for intentionally pure hydrogen production as fuel.

technology: Catalytic cracking with co-processing  5-10wt % of pyrolysis bio-oil
technology_description: Pyrolysis oil from biomass co-processed in a FCC unit together with fossil feed
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_refurbis: EUR2016
Building up the future cost of biofuels (SGAB, 2017)

Extra investment costs are based on adjustments that the FCC unit would need to apply in order to co-process the bio-oil. The production costs of this new feedstock are not included. Refineries may differ in terms of their investment needs and processing capabilities, this is a rough estimate of costs and they would mostly relate to new pipeline and feed nozzle for the pyrolysis bio-oil
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Building up the future cost of biofuels (SGAB, 2017)

Extra investment costs are based on adjustments that the FCC unit would need to apply in order to co-process the bio-oil. The production costs of this new feedstock are not included. Refineries may differ in terms of their investment needs and processing capabilities, this is a rough estimate of costs and they would mostly relate to new pipeline and feed nozzle for the pyrolysis bio-oil. The OPEX related to the bio-oil fraction in co-processing is not readily available for estimation, however, the SGAB report based its values on opinion from experts in the field. The basic numbers were used to arrive at a Rough Order of Magnitude (ROM) figure.
technical_lifetime_comment: assumption based on conventional catalytic cracking process

co2_emissions_source: CWT approach. Nederlandse lijst van energiedragers en standaard CO2 emissiefactoren, versie januari 2017 (RVO). CWT approach  is used by the sector organizations CONCAWE for benchmarking purposes. CWT stands Solomon “CO2 weighted tonne” (CWT) approach. Each process unit presents a standard CWT factor which refers to the net energy consumption and can be translated to CO2 emissions via the formula CO2 emissions = 1,083*0,0295*Unit throughtput*CWT factor.
co2_emissions_comment: emissions due to coke burning during catalyst regeneration. coke consumption based on expert consultation. emission factor for coke based on RVO list (94 kg CO2/GJ). Part of this coke is bio-genic, therefore the fossil emisssions were considered to reduce porportionally to the co-processing %
trl_source: Lammens, T. (2018). Advanced Biofuels from Fast Pyrolysis Bio-Oil. ETIP Bioenergy Workshop Emerging Technologies, Brussels. Fast pyrolysis oil from pinewood chips co-processing with vacuum gas oil in an FCC unit for second generation fuel production (Pinho, A., 2016)
trl_comment: Technology in demo phase. In Brazil there is a pilot plant of 150 kg/h capacity. A refinery in Sweden will start co-processing in 2021

CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen (VNPI, 2018)

The source mentions 0,5-1,5 MEUR/MWth for a generic hydrogen furnace of 10 MWth. The costs include extra pipeline, hydrogen compressor and burners adjustement. the average cost only for the adjustment of the furnace's burners is around 100 kEUR 2017/MWth. The costs for NOX emissions reduction abatement is not considered here, but this device is needed. The extra pipeline can difer significantly depending on the site.  The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0,7.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen (VNPI, 2018)
The source mentions 1% of CAPEX for the fixed OPEX.

Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.

Investment costs for capture, purification, compression, and transport network connection. Network connection costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year (Lensink and Schoots, 2021). CO2 purification and compression based on Berghout et al (2015). Lower limit considers that compression equipment is already present (only network connection is needed). Mid range costs are based on Berghout et al. (deflated from 2012 to 2020 EUR based on European HICP index), combined with compression/network costs from Lensink and Schoots 2021. Upper limit based on Danish Energy Agency/Energinet (2021a) considering only investments for CO2 compression & dehydration. Transport and storage equipment is excluded.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Based on: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.

3% of investment costs for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value. Storage costs assume Porthos tarriff, transportation assuming pipeline access. 8000 hours assumed.

investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Based on literature research. The result of the market consultation was 20 – 500 €/kW. Reference capacity is 20 MWth.

technology: Conventional production process (cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units, gasoline and benzene systems)
technology_description: Thermal conversion of organic feedstock to light olefins and aromatics. This includes cracking, cracked gas compression and distillation sections for products recovery and the downstream processes for butadiene, MTBE, pyrolysis gasoline and benzene production.
input_1_source: Interview with the company
input_1_comment: Based on the input of naphtha (4000 kt) and output of ethylene (1150 kt) in 2018.
input_2_source: Interview with the company
input_2_comment: The steam imported from the Swentibold power plant is superheated high-pressure steam (140 bar, 525°C). The total steam import in 2018 was around 7 PJ.
input_3_source: Interview with the company
input_3_comment: Methanol is used in the MTBE production unit. The process ratio is around 0.47 kt methanol/ MTBE produced.
input_4_source: Interview with the company
input_4_comment: Based on the total electricity consumption in 2018, which was 1 PJ for all the units combined.
output_1_comment: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
output_2_source: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
output_2_comment: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 680 kt of propylene. This  value was used to calculate the ratio kt propylene/kt ethylene. The lower limit relates to a naphtha cracker and was extracted from Boulamanti A. and Moya J.A. (2017).
output_3_source: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
output_3_comment: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 35 kt of hydrogen. This value was used to calculate the average ratio kt hydrogen/kt ethylene. Hydrogen is exported to other facilities in the Chemelot campus. The lower limit relates to a naphtha cracker and was extracted from Boulamant and Moya (2017).
output_4_source: Interview with the company
output_4_comment: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 4 kt of acetylene and this value was used for determining the average ratio kt acetylene/kt ethylene.
output_5_source: Interview with the company. Boulamanti A, & Moya JA. (2017b). Energy efficiency and GHG emissions: Prospective scenarios for the Chemical and Petrochemical Industry. https://doi.org/10.2760/630308.
output_5_comment: In 2018, SABIC Geleen produced around 110 kt of butadiene. This value was used to calculate the average ratio kt butadiene/kt ethylene. The upper limit was extracted Boulamanti and Moya (2017).
output_6_comment: The pyrolysis gasoline is partially used as feedstock for the benzene extraction unit (around 1020 kt In 2018). SABIC Geleen produced around 110 kt of hydrogen and this value was used to determine the average ratio kt pyrolysis gasoline/kt ethylene.
output_9_comment: This oil is used as feedstock for the carbon black industry.
output_10_comment: Steam (around 18 bar)  sourced from compressors which is exported to other facilities in Chemelot.
output_11_comment: The steam cracking reaction produces a methane-rich gas which is used to provide the needed heat for the furnaces. A small fraction of this fuel gas is exported to USG and used as fuel in boilers. In 2018 the value of residual gas exported was 44 kt. An average LHV of 50,24 GJ/t was used,  based on information from the Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).
co2_emissions_source: Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).Ren, T., Patel, M., & Blok, K. (2006). Olefins from conventional and heavy feedstocks: Energy use in steam cracking and alternative processes. Energy. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2005.04.001
co2_emissions_comment: Direct  emissions calculated based on total site's energy consumption. The emission factor for fuel gas (54.2 kg CO2/GJ) was extracted from Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015). The lower and upper values were based on Ren et al. (2006).
trl_comment: Proven technology already widely commercially available. Similar technology for steam cracking is used in other sites in The Netherlands (Dow Terneuzen and Shell Moerdijk).

technology: Full electrification of cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units and gasoline and benzene systems.
technology_description: Electrical furnaces for steam cracking conversion.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Römgens, B., & Dams, M. (2018). VNPI CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen. November 2018
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The source mentions investments of 3,5 to 5 MEUR/MW thermal for a generic electric furnace of 10 MWthermal. The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0,7.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Römgens, B., & Dams, M. (2018). VNPI CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen. November 2018
The source assumed the fixed OPEX is 2% of the CAPEX.
input_1_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_2_comment: The steam imported from the Swentibold power plant is superheated high-pressure steam (140 bar, 525°C). The total steam import in 2018 was around 7 PJ. It was assumed that full electrification of furnaces would not change the steam import, since it was considered that the superheating of the steam produced in the furnaces would continue to happen via electrical heating. For details see the MIDDEN report.
input_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_4_comment: The electricity consumption encompasses both current electricty demand and the additional demand for electrical cracking. For the electrity demand of the furnaces, a thermal efficiency of 98,5% is considered (93,5% was considered for the conventional furnaces). The naphtha pre-heating and the steam super-heating are considered to be done via electrical heating, therefore, no changes in the steam flows were considered.
output_1_comment: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
output_2_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_4_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_5_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_6_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_7_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_8_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_9_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_10_comment: Steam (around 18 bar)  sourced from compressors which is exported to other facilities in Chemelot. It is assumed that the steam balance remains the same when electrical furnaces are in place. This is a rough assumption because it is expected that the heat network would be significanlty effected by this technology.
output_11_comment: With electrified furnaces, there will be more residual gas available.
output_12_comment: It was assumed that the electrical cracking process would present the same material yields as the conventional process.
co2_emissions_comment: Direct  emissions from the cracking furnaces are avoided. Only the emissions due to flaring are assumed to remain. The flaring emissions were around 8 kt in 2018. For full assessment of the CO2 emissions, the source of electricity should also  be taken into account.
trl_source: IEA (2020). ETP Clean Energy Technology Guide.
trl_comment: Electric  furnaces are already commonly used in steel production and in glass production. The technology offers the possibility to be adapted to other high-temperature heat processes that are currently difficult to electrify, such as cracking furnaces from steam crackers.

technology: Electric boilers supply steam to cracking furnaces, butadiene and MTBE units and gasoline and benzene systems.
technology_description: The current steam import is considered to be substituted by steam from electrical boilers.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Berenschot (2017). Electrification in the Dutch process industry. In-depth study of promising transition pathways and innovation opportunities for electrification in the Dutch process industry.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The investment costs are based on a 70 MWe input boiler. The original values were 150-190 kEUR2017/MWe. The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0.7  and a capacity of 222 MWe, based on the steam demand. The figures include equipment and electrical connection costs. The latter may vary significantly depending on the site. Therefore, the estimated figure might not represent the actual situation for the SABIC Geleen site.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Berenschot (2017). Electrification in the Dutch process industry. In-depth study of promising transition pathways and innovation opportunities for electrification in the Dutch process industry.

The report of Berenschot presents OPEX costs for a 70 MWe input boiler. The original value is 1,1 kEUR2017/MWe/y. The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0,7 and a capacity of 222,2 MWe calculated for the steam demand of SABIC.
input_1_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_2_comment: The electricity consumption includes both the current electricty demand and the additional demand of electrical boilers. The steam demand in 2018 (7 PJ) was considered for the calculations, as well a thermal efficiency of 99,9% for the electrical boilers.
input_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.

The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.

output_11_comment: The steam cracking reaction produces a methane-rich gas which is used to provide the needed heat for the furnaces. A small fraction of this fuel gas is exported to USG and used as fuel in boilers. In 2018 the value of residual gas exported was 44 kt. technology: Cracking with hydrogen as fuel.  Hydrogen compression. Separation with hydrogen furnaces.

trl_comment: The methanol production process is still under development.The MTO process is widely used in large scales in Asia.

technology: Partial electrification of cracking furnaces (30-70%). Butadiene and MTBE units. Gasoline and benzene systems.
technology_description: Thermal demand from cracking furnaces is partially delivered by electricity.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Römgens, B., & Dams, M. (2018). VNPI CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen. November 2018
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The source mentions investments of 3,5 to 5 MEUR/MWthermal for a generic electric furnace of 10 MWthermal. The costs were adjusted using a scaling factor of 0,7. The central value assumed electrification of 50% of the cracking capacity.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Römgens, B., & Dams, M. (2018). VNPI CO2 Reductie Roadmap van de Nederlandse raffinaderijen. November 2018
The source assumed the fixed OPEX is 2% of the CAPEX.
input_1_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_2_source: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report
input_2_comment: The steam imported from the Swentibold power plant is superheated high-pressure steam (140 bar, 525°C). The total steam import in 2018 was around 7 PJ. It was assumed that the partial electrification of furnaces would not change the steam import, since it was considered that the superheating of the steam produced in the furnaces would continue to happen via electrical heating. For details see the MIDDEN report.
input_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_4_comment: The electricity consumption encompasses both current electricty demand and the additional demand for electrical cracking assuming electrification of 50% of the furnaces. For the electrity demand of the furnaces, a thermal efficiency of 98,5% is considered (93,5% was considered for the conventional furnaces). The naphtha pre-heating and the steam super-heating are considered to be done via electrical heating, therefore, no changes in the steam flows were considered.  The lower limit assumes electrification of 70% of furnaces and the upper limit electrification of 30% of furnaces. on.
output_1_comment: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
output_2_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_4_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_5_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.

output_7_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_8_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_9_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_10_comment: Steam (around 18 bar)  sourced from compressors which is exported to other facilities in Chemelot. It is assumed that the steam balance remains the same when furnaces are partially electrified.
output_11_comment: With electrified furnaces (assuming electrification of 50% of furnaces), there will be more residual gas available. The lower limit assumes electrification of 70% of furnaces and the upper limit electrification of 30% of furnaces. on.
output_12_comment: Same material yields as the conventional process were assumed
co2_emissions_comment: Direct  emissions calculated based on total site's energy consumption, assuming electrification of 50% of the furnaces. The emission factor for fuel gas (54.2 kg CO2/GJ) was extracted from Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015). The lower limit assumes electrification of 70% of furnaces and the upper limit electrification of 30% of furnaces.
trl_source: IEA (2020). ETP Clean Energy Technology Guide.
trl_comment: Electric  furnaces are already commonly used in steel production and in glass production. The technology offers the possibility to be adapted to other high-temperature heat processes that are currently difficult to electrify, such as cracking furnaces from steam crackers.

technology: Cracking furnaces with electrical compressors. Butadiene and MTBE units. Gasoline and benzene systems.
technology_description: Thermal demand from cracking furnaces is partially delivered by electricity.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The original source mentions 2,1-4,2 MEUR/MWe for full electrification of compressors for the SABIC site in Geleen and an electrical capacity of 177 MWe.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report
The source assumed the fixed OPEX is 2% of the CAPEX.
input_1_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_2_source: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report
input_2_comment: The steam import is reduced because the compressors no longer need steam to run. It was considered that the available steam from the furnaces is used on site to meet the demand of the other downstream units, resulting in around 2,4 PJ/yr of imported steam. The quality of this steam is yet undefined because each downstream process uses a different steam level. Most likely it would be high pressure steam. More details about this configuration can be found in the MIDDEN+ report.
input_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_4_comment: The electricity consumption includes both the current electricity demand and the additional demand of electrical compressors. For the compressors an efficiency of 90% was assumed.
output_1_comment: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
output_2_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_4_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.

output_6_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_7_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_8_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_9_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
output_10_comment: The steam cracking reaction produces a methane-rich gas which is used to provide the needed heat for the furnaces. A small fraction of this fuel gas is exported to USG and used as fuel in boilers. In 2018 the value of residual gas exported was 44 kt. An average LHV of 50,24 GJ/t was used,  based on information from the Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015). With electrical compressors in place, no changes in the fuel gas consumption within SABIC are expected.
output_11_comment: Same material yields as the conventional process were assumed
co2_emissions_source: Milieujaarverslag 2015 Site Chemelot (2015).Ren, T., Patel, M., & Blok, K. (2006). Olefins from conventional and heavy feedstocks: Energy use in steam cracking and alternative processes. Energy. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2005.04.001
co2_emissions_comment: Direct  emissions are the same as the conventional case because currently SABIC imports steam from Swentibold power plant. However, the scope 2 emissions could be reduced depending on the grid's emission factor.
trl_comment: Electrical compressors are proven technology, already widely commercially available. However, it is not common to have electrical compressors in steam cracking facilities instead of steam-driven compressors.

technology: Full electrification of cracking furnaces and compressors. Butadiene and MTBE units. Gasoline and benzene systems.
technology_description: Thermal demand from cracking furnaces is partially delivered by electricity.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report

Combined costs from full electrification of furnaces and electrical compressors.
input_1_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_2_source: West, K., Oliveira, C., Moncada, J. B. and Apeldoorn, T.(in prep.), Pathways to industrial decarbonisation in the Netherlands: paper & board and steam cracking, TNO report
input_2_comment: For this configuration, it was assumed that the steam superheating was no longer done via electrical heating. Therefore, the heat delivered by the furnaces to the downstream units is reduced and the external demand increases by around 0,8 PJ/yr compared to the consumption in 2018 (7 PJ). More details about this configuration can be found in the MIDDEN+ report. The steam quality is uncertain. Medium pressure steam was assumed.
input_3_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.
input_4_comment: The electricity consumption encompasses both current electricty demand and the additional demand for electrical cracking. For the electrity demand of the furnaces, a thermal efficiency of 98,5% is considered (93,5% was considered for the conventional furnaces).  For the electricity demand of the compressors, a thermal efficiency of 90% is assumed.
output_1_comment: The steam cracking process produces different products. Ethylene was chosen as main output for simplicity. Normally, the benchmark of this process groups the output as high value chemicals (HVC), which includes: hydrogen, acetylene, ethylene, propylene, butadiene and benzene. The total HVC production from SABIC in 2018 was 2259 kt.
output_2_comment: The material flows were considered to remain the same as in the conventional steam cracking process.

output_10_comment: With electrified furnaces, there will be more residual gas available.
output_11_comment: Same material yields as the conventional process were assumed
co2_emissions_comment: Direct  emissions from the cracking furnaces are avoided. Only the emissions due to flaring are assumed to remain. The flaring emissions were around 8 kt in 2018. For full assessment of the CO2 emissions, the source of electricity should also  be taken into account.
trl_source: IEA (2020). ETP Clean Energy Technology Guide.
trl_comment: Electric  furnaces are already commonly used in steel production and in glass production. The technology offers the possibility to be adapted to other high-temperature heat processes that are currently difficult to electrify, such as cracking furnaces from steam crackers. Electrical compressors are proven technology already widely commercially available. Therefore, the limitation exists mainly in the development of electrical cracking.

technology_description: The electric boiler uses electricity to generate low pressure steam.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC, Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a.. Technology Data for Generation of Electricity and District Heating, Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020b.. Jansen, N., de Smidt, R.P., Hermelink, M., Eindverslag Haalbaarheidsstudie Elektrificatie bestaande gasketels,TNO, 2019.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: The investment is based on the SDE++ subsidy advice (Lensink, 2020) for a large-scale electric boiler. It includes direct costs (boiler, superheater, pump systems, on-site electricity infrastructure, piping, measuring equipment, civil works, scaffolding and cranes) and indirect costs (engineering, supervision), but it does not include unforeseen costs and it is assumed that an existing grid connection can be used. The lower limit is based on the investment for a 15 MWth electric boiler, including equipment costs (85%) and installation costs (15%) (DEA/Energinet, 2020a). The upper value is based on the investment for a 1-5 MW electric boiler and includes grid connection fees (DEA/Energinet, 2020b). In some cases, the required investments for a grid connection can be higher (Jansen, e.a. 2019).
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Electrification of industry. Facilitating the integration of offshore wind with Power-to-Heat in industry, Akzo Nobel, Deltalinqs, Shell & TenneT, DNV GL, 2018..Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC, Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a.

We assume fixed operation and maintenance costs equal to 2% of the equipment costs (DNV GL, 2018). We assume that equipment costs make up 85% of the investment (DEA/Energinet, 2020a). As in Lensink (2020), we do not assume variable operating and maintenance costs. The O&M costs exclude costs for materials and energy. Any levies, taxes or subsidies (which may be linked to products, raw materials and emissions) are not included. Connection tariffs, supply and metering fees, costs for contracted capacity and transport tariffs are not included.
technical_lifetime_source: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Electrification of industry. Facilitating the integration of offshore wind with Power-to-Heat in industry, Akzo Nobel, Deltalinqs, Shell & TenneT, DNV GL, 2018.. Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC, Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020.
technical_lifetime_comment: Lensink (2020) assumes that there is no residual value after the 15 year SDE++ subsidy period. According to DNV GL (2018) the expected system lifetime is 12 years. DEA/Energinet (2020) assume a technical lifetime of 25 years.
input_1_source: Lensink, S. (2020), Eindadvies Basisbedragen SDE++ 2020, Den Haag: PBL.. Electrification of industry. Facilitating the integration of offshore wind with Power-to-Heat in industry, Akzo Nobel, Deltalinqs, Shell & TenneT, DNV GL, 2018.
input_1_comment: Calculated assuming an efficiency of 99% (Lensink, 2020). The upper limit is based on an efficiency of 95% (DNV GL, 2018).

technology_description: Retrofit of natural gas boiler to fire hydrogen. See Element Energy (2019) Conversion of Industrial Heating Equipment to Hydrogen for further information regarding retrofit. Source also states that a simple site can implement this by 2023 and complex site by 2025.

technical_lifetime_source: 25 y given in Hart, D., Howes, J., & Lehner, F. (2015). Scenarios for deployment of hydrogen in contributing to meeting carbon budgets and the 2050 target. 20 y given in Lux Research (2015), "Taking the C out of Steam”.

technology: Post-Combustion Carbon Capture and storage - gaseous transport
technology_description: This unit includes capturing and treatment of CO2, as well as pipelines. Gaseous transport is assumed
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: Including capture, purification, compression, and transport network connection. Costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year. High range from retrofit to existing installation, mid range based on new installation. Low range costs are based on Husebye et al. (2012) for 13.5%vol CO2 concentration (deflated from 2012 to 2020 EUR based on European HICP index), combined with compression/network costs from Lensink and Schoots (2021). Transport and storage equipment is excluded.
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
Considering the transportation, storage, and O&M costs. Storage costs assume Porthos tarriff, transportation assuming pipeline access. 8000 hours assumed.
technical_lifetime_source: Husebye, J., Brunsvold, A., Roussanaly, S., & Zhang, X. (2012). Techno economic evaluation of amine based CO2 capture: impact of CO2 concentration and steam supply .
input_1_comment: Present in the flue gases
input_2_source: Estimation based on: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN . Den Haag: PBL.
input_2_comment: 175 kWh per tonne captured. The main electricity consumers are the processes of compressing gases and for filtering, transport and storage
input_3_source: Based on: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN . Den Haag: PBL.
input_3_comment: 1028 kWh per tonne CO2
co2_emissions_comment: Estimation. The carbon capture unit has an efficiency of 90%. Therefore for each kt of CO2 captured 0.1 kt of CO2 remained in the emissions
trl_source: Global CCS Institute (2021). Technology Readiness and Costs of CCS.
trl_comment: MEA solvent capture and CO2 compression techniques have been commercially applied.

technology: Add-on CO2 capture & compression (high concentration) for gaseous transport
technology_description: Capture and compression of high-concentration CO2 streams (>95%vol) based on inherent separation in industrial processes, for gaseous transport (compressed to ~35 bar) (100% capture rate). Assumes that only compression and network connection are needed, capture is inherent to the process. Most often used in combination with pipeline transport.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: CAPEX for capture, purification, compression, and transport network connection. Network connection costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year (Lensink 2021). CO2 purification and compression based on Berghout et al (2015). Lower limit considers that compression equipment is already present (only network connection is needed). Mid range costs are based on Berghout et al. (deflated from 2012 to 2020 EUR based on European HICP index), combined with compression/network costs from Lensink 2021. Upper limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021) post-combustion capture for small CHP, considering only invesments for CO2 compression & dehydration. Transport and storage equipment is excluded (see Lensink 2021 Chapter 17 for cost estimates).
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
3% of CAPEX for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value.
technical_lifetime_source: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284. Husebye, J., Brunsvold, A., Roussanaly, S., & Zhang, X. (2012). Techno economic evaluation of amine based CO2 capture: impact of CO2 concentration and steam supply.
input_1_source: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
input_1_comment: See p 173 of Lensink (2021). 125 kWh/tCO2 for compression.  Upper limit based on Berghout et al. (2015), lower limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021).
output_1_comment: Note that CO2 captured is CO2 that has been captured and compressed to the appropriate level for transport.
co2_emissions_comment: Capture rate for inherent separation is 100%, based on the input gas stream. Note that avoided emissions may be lower depending on the utilities that provide the necessary electricity.
trl_source: Global CCS Institute (2021). Technology Readiness and Costs of CCS.
trl_comment: Inherent separation already occurs as part of the industrial process. CO2 compression is a well-known, commercially mature technique.

technology: Add-on CO2 capture & compression (high concentration) for liquefied transport
technology_description: Capture and compression of high-concentration CO2 streams (>95%vol) based on inherent separation in industrial processes, for liquefied transport (compressed to ~110 bar) (100% capture rate). Assumes that only compression/liquefaction and network connection are needed, capture is inherent to the process. Most often used in combination with transport by truck or ship.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_sour: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
investment_per_unit_of_capacity_new_comm: CAPEX for capture, purification, compression, and liquefaction.  Costs based on a unit with capacity of about 0.7 MtCO2 captured/year. Main value based on a new installation, upper limit based on a retrofit at an existing site. Transport and storage equipment is excluded (see Lensink 2021 Chapter 17 for cost estimates).
annual_operating_and_maintenance_costs_p: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL.
3% of CAPEX for fixed O&M costs. Transport and storage costs are excluded from this value.
technical_lifetime_source: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284. Husebye, J., Brunsvold, A., Roussanaly, S., & Zhang, X. (2012). Techno economic evaluation of amine based CO2 capture: impact of CO2 concentration and steam supply.
input_1_source: Lensink, S., & Schoots, K. (2021). EINDADVIES BASISBEDRAGEN SDE++ 2021. Den Haag: PBL. Danish Energy Agency/Energinet, 2020a, Technology Data Industrial process heat and CC. Berghout, N. et al. (2015). Techno-economic performance and spatial footprint of infrastructure configurations for large scale CO2 capture in industrial zones: A case study for the Rotterdam Botlek area. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control 39: 256-284.
input_1_comment: See p 173 of Lensink (2021). 162 kWh/tCO2 for liquefaction.  Upper limit based on Berghout et al. (2015), lower limit based on Danish Energy Agency (2021).
output_1_comment: Note that CO2 captured is CO2 that has been captured and compressed to the appropriate level for transport.
